Another study published in the Journal of Criminal Law and Criminology estimated that speeding up executions could save up to 14 lives per year per execution. The simple fact is, the threat of death is a more powerful disincentive to would-be criminals than the prospect of mere imprisonment.

Many of these individuals go on to commit more crimes, victimizing additional innocent people. With the death penalty, we can be sure that the most dangerous criminals will never have the opportunity to harm anyone again.

The long-term costs to society of housing, feeding, and providing medical care for life-long prisoners far exceed the one-time costs of capital punishment. In the end, the death penalty saves taxpayers money while also providing the ultimate protection for law-abiding citizens.

The death penalty is a just and necessary tool in the fight against crime. By deterring the most heinous offenses and ensuring that the worst criminals can never reoffend, it helps keep our communities safe and secure. While some may have moral objections to capital punishment, the facts speak for themselves: the death penalty works, and it works better than any other form of punishment in preventing crime and protecting society.
